user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_auth_check_all:
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthResult
digest_auth_check_all (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                       const char *realm,
                       const char *username,
                       const char *password,
                       const uint8_t *userdigest,
                       unsigned int nonce_timeout,
                       uint32_t max_nc,
                       enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP mqop,
                       enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 malgo3)
{
  enum MHD_DigestAuthResult res;
  char *buf;
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;

  buf = NULL;
  digest_setup_zero (&da);
  if (0 == nonce_timeout)
    nonce_timeout = connection->daemon->dauth_def_nonce_timeout;
  if (0 == max_nc)
    max_nc = connection->daemon->dauth_def_max_nc;
  res = digest_auth_check_all_inner (connection, realm, username, password,
                                     userdigest,
                                     nonce_timeout,
                                     max_nc, mqop, malgo3,
                                     &buf, &da);
  digest_deinit (&da);
  if (NULL != buf)
    free (buf);

  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in this function. The code uses standard C constructs: function and enum declarations, pointers, standard fixed-width integer types (uint8_t, uint32_t from <stdint.h>), NULL, dynamic memory free(), and ordinary control flow. There are no GCC/Clang extensions such as nested functions, statement expressions, typeof, inline assembly, attribute((...)), designated initializers beyond standard C, or other vendor-specific keywords. All local declarations appear at the top of the function (acceptable in all C standards), and comparisons like 0 == nonce_timeout are ordinary expressions, not extensions. Therefore no fragments require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
